title: Webinterface not working, running under Fedora 31
body:
<!-- Hey, annotations like this one will not be visible in your ticket, just ignore them all. -->

### Describe the problem
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. -->

<!-- WRITE HERE -->

Yesterday I updated my server operating system from Fedora 29 to 31.
Since then I cannot access the webinterface anymore. Neither https://domain.tld:8001 or my subdomain using a reverse proxy are working anymore.

After the update I made sure the necessary python2 packages were installed. I am currently running version 2.7.17.
I start pyload using the following command:
`/usr/bin/python2 /usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/pyLoadCore.py --configdir=/root/.pyload/`

That gives me the following output:

```
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Starting pyLoad 0.4.9
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Using home directory: /root/.pyload
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Activated plugins: Checksum, ClickNLoad, EventMapper, ExternalScripts, UnSkipOnFail, UpdateManager, UserAgentSwitcher, XFileSharing
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Deactivate plugins: AndroidPhoneNotify, AntiStandby, AntiVirus, AppriseNotify, BypassCaptcha, Captcha9Kw, CloudFlareDdos, DeathByCaptcha, DeleteFinished, DiscordNotifier, DownloadScheduler, ExpertDecoders, ExtractArchive, HotFolder, IRC, ImageTyperz, JustPremium, LinkFilter, LinkdecrypterComHook, LogMarker, MergeFiles, MultiHome, PushBullet, PushOver, RestartFailed, SkipRev, TransmissionRPC, WindowsPhoneNotify, XMPP
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Downloadtime: True
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Free space: 97.24 GiB
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Starting threaded SSL webserver: 0.0.0.0:8001
10.12.2019 11:13:12 INFO      Activating Accounts...
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      Activating Plugins...
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      ADDON XFileSharing: Auto-discover new hosters
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      ADDON XFileSharing: Auto-discover new crypters
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      pyLoad is up and running
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      ADDON UpdateManager: pyLoad is up to date!
10.12.2019 11:13:13 INFO      ADDON UpdateManager: All plugins are up to date!
```

As soon as I try to access the webinterface in a browser the following messages appear:
```
Exception in thread Thread-5:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/threading.py", line 804, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/web/ServerThread.py", line 71, in run
    self.start_threaded()
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/web/ServerThread.py", line 93, in start_threaded
    webinterface.run_threaded(host=self.host, port=self.port, cert=self.cert, key=self.key)
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/web/webinterface.py", line 156, in run_threaded
    run(app=web, host=host, port=port, server=CherryPyWSGI, quiet=True)
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/lib/bottle.py", line 2383, in run
    server.run(app)
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/web/utils.py", line 137, in run
    server.start()
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/lib/wsgiserver/__init__.py", line 1607, in start
    self.tick()
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/lib/wsgiserver/__init__.py", line 1678, in tick
    conn = self.ConnectionClass(s, self.wsgi_app, environ)
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyload-stable/module/lib/wsgiserver/__init__.py", line 1142, in __init__
    if SSL and isinstance(sock, SSL.ConnectionType):
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'ConnectionType'
```
I am not very experienced using python but of course I suspect that something has changed with the update to the lastest Fedora version. Especially since python2 support has been dropped from this release. Maybe downgrading to another python2 version could help?

If it is of any help my virtual host configuration for the reverse proxy running under a subdomain looks like this:
```
###Pyload###
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName pyload.domain.tld
    ServerAlias www.pyload.domain.tld
    RedirectMatch permanent ^/(.*) https://pyload.domain.tld/$1
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:443>
    ServerName pyload.domain.tld
    ServerAlias www.pyload.domain.tld
    ProxyPreserveHost On

    # setup the proxy
    <Proxy *>
        Order allow,deny
        Allow from all
    </Proxy>
    ProxyPass / https://localhost:8001/
    ProxyPassReverse / https://localhost:8001/
</VirtualHost>
```

Any help would be really appreciated. I love pyload!

### Debug log
<!-- Enable `Debug Mode` in pyload's general settings. -->

<!-- WRITE HERE BELOW -->
Running in Debug mode is giving the same error output as stated above.

title: Container file name containing non-ASCII characters are not recognized
body:
<!-- Hey, annotations like this one will not be visible in your ticket, just ignore them all. -->

### Describe the problem
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. -->
When I add a package in the webinterface, I enter a name: `test` and provide a container: `°.torrent`
As ° is a non-ASCII character, the file is not recognized and pyLoad only provides the log below.

As a workaround I rename the file and I encounter #3466 .

title: Mediafire only download one link at time
body:

title: [PremiumTo] File name?
body:
<!-- Hey, annotations like this one will not be visible in your ticket, just ignore them all. -->

Hi all,
when downloading files from uploaded.net the downloaded files are not named correctly.
That means when downloading something like uploaded.net/file/abcdefg1 the name of the downloaded file is just abcdefg1. 
Any suggestions?

Thanks for your support!

title: PyLoad's frontend asset links fail to conform to set Path Prefix
body:
<!-- Hey, annotations like this one will not be visible in your ticket, just ignore them all. -->

### Describe the problem
I put PyLoad behind Traefik, with a `PathPrefix` of `/example/pyload`. I set the Path Prefix in PyLoad's backend to `/example/pyload`.

Visiting `/example/pyload` in a browser successfully redirects to `/example/pyload/login`, where the login process can be completed, again successfully.

However, frontend layout assets fail to fetch and render. A cursory glance of the network logs show requests that *do not* conform to the Path Prefix set on PyLoad's backend.
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. -->

<!-- WRITE HERE -->


### Debug log
Here's Firefox's console output when visiting the login page:
```
Loading failed for the <script> with source “https://host/media/js/modern/jquery-3.2.1.min.js”. login:295:1
The resource from “https://host/media/js/modern/jquery-ui-1.12.1.min.js” was blocked due to MIME type (“text/plain”) mismatch (X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff).
login
Loading failed for the <script> with source “https://host/media/js/modern/jquery-ui-1.12.1.min.js”. login:296:1
The resource from “https://host/media/js/modern/jquery.peekabar.min.js” was blocked due to MIME type (“text/plain”) mismatch (X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff).
login
Loading failed for the <script> with source “https://host/media/js/modern/jquery.peekabar.min.js”. login:297:1
The resource from “https://host/media/js/modern/bootstrap.min.js” was blocked due to MIME type (“text/plain”) mismatch (X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff).
login
Loading failed for the <script> with source “https://host/media/js/modern/bootstrap.min.js”. login:298:1
The resource from “https://host/media/js/modern/base.js” was blocked due to MIME type (“text/plain”) mismatch (X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff).
login
Loading failed for the <script> with source “https://host/media/js/modern/base.js”.
```

If we look at the last unloaded resource, visiting the following URL successfully loads it: `https://host/example/pyload/media/js/modern/base.js`.

PyLoad's frontend resource URIs should conform to the Path Prefix set by the user.

title: autologin option ignored and removed upon start
body:
### Describe the problem
It seems like the autologin functionality is not working: When adding the `autologin` option to the `webinterface` section of the configuration file, the option is removed upon restart by pyload. Thus, it is never applied and the autologin functionality not working.

```python
webinterface - "Webinterface":
	...
	bool autologin : "Skip login if single user" = True
```

### Expected behavior
- Setting the configuration file as given by the example above
- Browse to the pyload instance and access without login (considering that there is only one user existing)

### Actual behavior
- Setting the configuration file as given by the example above
- Browse to the pyload instance and be presented with a login screen (i.e. no autologin)
- Upon verifying the settings in the configuration file discovering that the previous `autlogin` parameter is missing:

```python
webinterface - "Webinterface":
	...
```

### To reproduce
- Set the `autlogin` option as described in the example above

### Debug log

title: Update download queue entry with file name
body:
<!--- Hey, annotations like this one will not be shown in your issue ticket, so you don't have to delete them, just ignore them all -->

- [ ] Other


### Summary:
<!--- Please explain what's the issue -->

<!--- WRITE HERE - REQUIRED -->
Hi, 
I noticed that at least with shareonline, the name of the queue entry is always the URL.
This is inconventient, if I try to match real files with queue entries.

`{"status": 3, "format_size": "0.00 B", "name": "http://www.share-online.biz/dl/##########", "plugin": "ShareonlineBiz", "url": "http://www.share-online.biz/dl/##########", "packageID": 91, "fid": 1287, "error": "", "statusmsg": "eingereiht", "icon": "status_queue.png", "order": 0, "size": 0},`

But, the source code of ShareonlineBiz.py contains the function `api_info`, which is able to retrieve the File Name.
I expected that at latest when the DL is started, the name will be upgraded.

### How to reproduce:
<!--- Please explain what someone needs to do in order to see what's described above -->

Enqueue a DL link; it will only be called by its URL, even after starting a download.


### Expected behavior:
<!--- Please explain what should happen -->

This is more a question:
__Shouldn't it update the entry name to the file name?__
__When should this happen? While adding or at start of download?__
__If the current behaviour is unintended; can I help to change it?__

My Idea: 
`If link.name == link.url Then link.name = filename`

Or is "name" informal and another entry "filename" should be added to the database?
`link.filename = filename`

<!--- WRITE HERE - OPTIONAL -->


### Actual behavior:
<!--- Please explain what actually happens -->

<!--- WRITE HERE - OPTIONAL -->


### Debug log:
<!--- Enable `Debug Mode` in pyload `General` settings and add it here -->
pyLoad knows the name...

title: Forward navigation buttons in Logs page do not respect the Path Prefix
body:
In the Logs page, the "Forward one page" and "Forward to last page" buttons do not respect the Path Prefix option, and results in a 404 when clicked. 

For example, I have the Path Prefix set to /pyload, and the "Back one page" and "Back to first page" navigation buttons work fine (has the URL https://my.domain/pyload/logs/1). However the forward buttons have "https://my.domain/logs/1" and "https://my.domain/logs/" as their URL, respectively.

Using latest 0.4.9 version. It is being accessed through a nginx reverse proxy, but considering this has been the only broken link I've found so far, I'm inclined to believe that this is not a proxy config problem

title: No Capcha displayed with SSL enabled
body:
Hello,

with SSL enabled, no capcha will be shown in the popup.
only:
`The captcha may take a few seconds to load.

Note: to solve this interactive captchas
Please install the Tampermonkey add-on in your browser and add the pyload userscript.`

With SSL disabled everything works fine.

The configuration ist the same, except SSL on/off

With apache reverse proxy it shows the same behavior:
pyload (without ssl) -> apache http -> working
pyload (without ssl) -> apache https -> not working

installed version from: https://github.com/pyload/pyload/issues/3283
server: threaded

can this issue be related to Tampermonkey or pyload?

regards
Klaus

title: Python Web Interface on macOS Safari Can't Add Downloads
body:
Hi, apologies if this issue has already come up, I tried searching the issues, but didn't spot anything. I'm pretty new to submitting issues so let me know if there's any other useful information I can cobble together.

I just set up a pyload install on my raspberry pi with the pyplex web interface template and I noticed that the web interface does not appear to (fully) work on desktop Safari. While the downloads can be browsed and configuration settings changed (e.g., adding accounts), downloads cannot be added. 

Reproduce: 
(1) open WebUI in Safari on desktop
(2) try to add any link
(3) check logs - no messages related to the added link appear and the link is not added

Conclusion that it was a problem with desktop safari drawn from:
(1) download links could be added via CLI
(2) download links could be added using Firefox 
(3) download links could be added using Safari on iOS

Safari: Version 11.1.2 (13605.3.8)
Operating System: macOS High Sierra 10.13.6 (17G65)

title: FreeNAS ZFS freeSpace problem

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
Hello,

pyLoad (stable branch) say a completly strange freespace (more than available).

I have solved my problem with the change of one line in module/utils.py (line 113) :
`        return s.f_bsize * s.f_bavail`
to
`        return s.f_frsize * s.f_bavail`

body: Is pyLoad Webserver indexed by BigG or other search engine (DuckDuckGo, SHODAN, etc.)? Is there a way to protect it, I don't know, for example with a 2FA access? I know I can whitelist some IP but when I remotely access I have always different IPs.

title: Unicode hyphen crashes ascii codec
body:
There is a special kind of hyphen which just causes pyLoad to blow chunks - if the file name includes it. I think that it is the one the Microsoft word auto-replaces a "normal" minus sign with when two words are hyphenated. This is it: "–" (compare it to a "normal" minus sign "-"). I normally use Click n Load, & have done for several years. If the file name includes the malignant hyphen, it errors and crashes instantly. If you use the "add" button on the WebInterface, & paste the file name (that includes this hyphen) into the "Package Name" field, it will "add" it for download, but as soon as it starts to process the download, it crashes. I have added these debugs to the bottom of the post.

I'm sorry to say that this bug has existed for some years, it has just taken me a while to finally track down the cause to a unicode hyphen, as I didn't want to report a sporadic bug with an unknown cause that I couldn't reliably replicate. However, now that I can replicate this 100%, if you need a working example, pm me and I can provide a username, password, & link that you can test.

Here is the debug log of what happens. Note the file name in the logs "**Package \xe2\x80\x93 April 2017**" which originally was "**Package – April 2017**" on the link.


**This is the Click n Load generated error**
```

title: pyload time (in debug log) always is one hour behind
body:
Hello!

This is a problem, I have noticed long time ago, already. The time in pyload's debug log always is one hour behind current time on the router that pyload is running on. It was same on multiple installations on different devices.

title: FREENAS JAIL (6TB ZFS) - IndexError: list index out of range
body:

title: Fix for MegaCoNz URLs not being recognized from API request

milestone.title: pyLoad Next
milestone.description:
Future Release.

- All plugins updated
- Critical bugs fixup
- New UpdateManager
- New config module
- New git structure
- No setup
- Fix SSL support
- Full code refactoring
- PyPI support
- Update built-in Python 2.x to latest
- Update built-in lib to latest
- Update built-in unrar to latest

body:
Pertaining the [issue priorly described here](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/issues/2592), in /module/Api.py

replace this line:
`urlmatcher = re.compile(r"((https?|ftps?|xdcc|sftp):((//)|(\\\\))+[\w\d:#@%/;$()~_?\+\-=\\\.&]*)", re.IGNORECASE)`

with this line:
`urlmatcher = re.compile(r"((https?|ftps?|xdcc|sftp):((//)|(\\\\))+[\w\d:#!@%/;$()~_?\+\-=\\\.&]*)", re.IGNORECASE)`

The difference being the addition of a "!". 

It turns out, as it [can be tested](https://regex101.com/#python), that the regex expression was not matching MegaCoNz URLS where a # is followed by a ! such as in:
https://mega.nz/#!ENVCXBgLetcetcetc

Does not seem to affect the recognition of other hosters but can not guarantee it.

title: [RequestFactory] getRequest(): Lock is not released when requesting a 'XDCC' request

milestone.title: pyLoad Next
milestone.description:
Future Release.

- All plugins updated
- Critical bugs fixup
- New UpdateManager
- New config module
- New git structure
- No setup
- Fix SSL support
- Full code refactoring
- PyPI support
- Update built-in Python 2.x to latest
- Update built-in lib to latest
- Update built-in unrar to latest

body:
RequestFactory's Lock is acquired ([RequestFactory.py#L44](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/network/RequestFactory.py#L44)) but not released ([RequestFactory.py#L54](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/network/RequestFactory.py#L54)) if you request a 'XDCC' request.
The function returns without releasing the lock.

Proper function should be:

``` python
    def getRequest(self, pluginName, account=None, type="HTTP"):
        self.lock.acquire()

        if type == "XDCC":
            req = XDCCRequest(proxies=self.getProxies())

        else:
            req = Browser(self.bucket, self.getOptions())

            if account:
                cj = self.getCookieJar(pluginName, account)
                req.setCookieJar(cj)
            else:
                req.setCookieJar(CookieJar(pluginName))

        self.lock.release()
        return req
```

title: Getting html response when BadHeader is encountered

milestone.title: pyLoad Next
milestone.description:
Future Release.

- All plugins updated
- Critical bugs fixup
- New UpdateManager
- New config module
- New git structure
- No setup
- Fix SSL support
- Full code refactoring
- PyPI support
- Update built-in Python 2.x to latest
- Update built-in lib to latest
- Update built-in unrar to latest

body:
It appears that Rapidgator enjoys playing with return codes:

```
% curl -D head 'http://rapidgator.net/api/file/download?sid=[...]&url=http://rapidgator.net/file/[...]'
{"response":null,"response_status":505,"response_details":"Delay between downloads must be not less than 0 min. Don`t want to wait? Upgrade to Premium and forget about delays!"}
% head -1 head 
HTTP/1.1 505
```

Likewise, it will throw a 503 error with "response_details" matching `DOWNLOAD_LIMIT_ERROR_PATTERN` if we're out of downloads for the hour. The way pyload currently handles such "BadHeaders" is to throw an exception in the process of which the content of the actual webpage is unrecoverably lost. However, this content contains crucial information. I don't see a way of fixing this without touching `HTTPRequest.py` which should not be done in the stable branch, am I right? What are the options to get the content of the HTTP response even though the header contains a "bad" code?

at the moment there is no way to add an intermediate certificate when using the threaded webserver.

i tried to make a pull-request, but unfortunatelly I can't make it work adding the setting manually to the code:

[__ init __.py](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/lib/wsgiserver/__init__.py)
`ctx.use_certificate_chain_file( ... )`

in order to harden the webserver a little and remove ssl warnings from newer browers, the default ciphers should also be adapted:

```
ctx.set_cipher_list('HIGH:!aNULL:!MD5:!RC4')                                                
ctx.set_options(SSL.OP_NO_SSLv3)
```

title: [Bug] "download_finished" event is fired before pyfile status is set

milestone.title: pyLoad Next
milestone.description:
Future Release.

- All plugins updated
- Critical bugs fixup
- New UpdateManager
- New config module
- New git structure
- No setup
- Fix SSL support
- Full code refactoring
- PyPI support
- Update built-in Python 2.x to latest
- Update built-in lib to latest
- Update built-in unrar to latest

body:
In plugins/internal/Addon.py, the function called after each finished download is defined like that : 

``` python
#: Deprecated method, use `download_finished` instead (Remove in 0.4.10)
def downloadFinished(self, pyfile):
    if pyfile.hasStatus("finished"):  #: Check if still "finished" (Fix in 0.4.10)
        return self.download_finished(pyfile)
```

The check was added recently and it appears it doesn't work, I had to comment the line to execute the script

``` python
#: Deprecated method, use `download_finished` instead (Remove in 0.4.10)
def downloadFinished(self, pyfile):
    #if pyfile.hasStatus("finished"):  #: Check if still "finished" (Fix in 0.4.10)
        return self.download_finished(pyfile)
```

The problem is that in module/PluginThread.py, the call to hookManager.downloadFinished is in start of method "run": 

``` python
 try:
                ...
                # start download
                ...
                self.m.log.info(_("Download finished: %s") % pyfile.name)
                self.m.core.hookManager.downloadFinished(pyfile)
                ...
```

but the status of the "pyfile" is set at the end of the method (pyfile.finishIfDone()): 

``` python
finally:
            ...
            pyfile.finishIfDone()
            ...
```

So when it enters in Addon.py, the status of the file is not "finished" yet

body:
Hi,
There is a bug in `ConfigParser.py` which is also present in v0.4.10:
If the description part or the value part of a line in the config file contains `=` (`:` too?)  characters (e.g. `Captcha9Kw`'s `hoster_options`), this line will not parsed correctly.
This also makes `plugin.conf` bigger on every `pyLoad` startup (see the size of `Captcha9Kw`'s `hoster_options` grows with every start)

Since its a core issue, nothing can be done in v0.4.9 beside removing `hoster_options` support from `Captcha9Kw`..

I will post a fix for v0.4.10

maybe this is the reason for the recent issues with config not saved

body:
Pyload stopped working over https for me. I have a StartCom SSL Certificate that requires an intermediate certificate to be delivered to the browser. So I included it in ssl.crt in addition to my server certificate. This setup worked for 2 years until now.

Since today Chrome and Safari give ssl-warnings because only the server certificate and not the intermediate certificate is delivered by the threaded server, so the ssl trust chain is broken. I didn't change my configuration or whatever. There are no Warnings in the Log. I tried to include the StartCom root CA certificate in ssl.crt without any luck. Connecting to Pyload by using the ip and ignoring the ssl warning works (HTST is activated). All permissions for conf files, logs, certificates etc. are set correctly.

My conf:

ssl - "SSL":
        file cert : "SSL Certificate" = /etc/myssl/ssl.crt
        bool activated : "Activated" = True
        file key : "SSL Key" = /etc/myssl/ssl.key

webinterface - "Webinterface":
        str template : "Template" = default
        bool activated : "Activated" = True
        str prefix : "Path Prefix" =
        builtin;threaded;fastcgi;lightweight server : "Server" = threaded
        ip host : "IP" = 0.0.0.0
        bool https : "Use HTTPS" = True
        int port : "Port" = 9001

-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
Server Certificate

title: pyLoadGui error No module named Connector
body:
Starting pyLoadGui results in the error message

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/pyLoadGui", line 41, in <module>
    from module.gui.Connector import Connector
ImportError: No module named Connector
```

followed by the termination of the program. The cause of this issue is, that the file of the Connector module in module/gui/ is acutually called "connector.py" with a lowercase c. On arch (and I'd guess any other) linux this prevents python from finding the file.

This can easily be fixed by changing [line 41](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/pyLoadGui.py#L41) to

```
from module.gui.connector import Connector
```

or alternatively renaming "module/gui/connector.py" to "Connector.py"

Thank you.

body:
Hi,

form `PluginManager.py`:

``` python
    def parse(self, folder, pattern=False, home={}):


        for f in listdir(pfolder):


                name = f[:-3]
                if name[-1] == ".": name = name[:-4]



                    try:
                        self.core.config.addPluginConfig(name, config, desc)
                    except:
                        self.log.error("Invalid config in %s: %s" % (name, config))
```

The problem is, if there are at least two plugins with the same name (say hook and hoster) - like there was with `HighWayMe`, one plugin overwrite the other''s setting.
This also happens in `0.4.10` too (https://github.com/vuolter/pyload/blob/0.4.10/pyload/manager/Plugin.py).
the correct desired behavior should be a merge of all settings from all plugins of the same name, then ,when all plugins parsing finished, removing all other unused setting of that section on `plugin.conf`

title: Trouble starting download with sleeping drive
body:
The drive that my pyload uses goes into sleep mode (spin down) after 2h of idle. If I add some files now I get errors like these:

```
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/share/pyload/module/PluginThread.py", line 186, in run
    self.m.core.hookManager.downloadPreparing(pyfile)
  File "/usr/share/pyload/module/utils.py", line 165, in new
    return func(*args)
  File "/usr/share/pyload/module/HookManager.py", line 214, in downloadPreparing
    plugin.downloadPreparing(pyfile)
  File "/home/pi/.pyload/userplugins/hooks/UserAgentSwitcher.py", line 43, in downloadPreparing
    pyfile.plugin.req.http.c.setopt(pycurl.USERAGENT, useragent)
error: cannot invoke setopt() - perform() is currently running
```

```
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/share/pyload/module/PluginThread.py", line 187, in run
    pyfile.plugin.preprocessing(self)
  File "/home/pi/.pyload/userplugins/internal/Plugin.py", line 269, in preprocessing
    return self.process(self.pyfile)
  File "/home/pi/.pyload/userplugins/hoster/BasePlugin.py", line 56, in process
    self.download(link, ref=False, disposition=True)
  File "/home/pi/.pyload/userplugins/internal/Plugin.py", line 512, in download
    makedirs(location, int(self.core.config["permission"]["folder"], 8))
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/os.py", line 157, in makedirs
    mkdir(name, mode)
OSError: [Errno 17] File exists: '/media/drive/folder'
```

There are some things I noticed and tried:

Upon adding, the download of the first file is startet multiple times. If the hoster allows multiDL its essentially startet as often as "Max Parallel Downloads" allows. "Max connections for one download" seems to have no influence. I have it set to 1.

After all these download threads have failed, the last one is left as "failed" in the list of running downloads. It can't be removed, and so the package that contains the failed download can't be.

I managed to solve this problem for a specific case. I have flexget set up to read some rss feeds at night. Usually the drive is asleep at this point of time. I call flexget via cron and simply added 

```
touch /media/drive/wakeup && rm /media/drive/wakeup &&
```

This way before pyload is even concerned, I wake up the drive by creating and immediately deleting an empty file called "wakeup".

So in my understanding the errors occur because of the multiple calling of the same download. So they are merely symptoms of the underlying problem, that the download is called multiple times in the first place. This on the other hand is caused by the sleeping HDD and I have no Idea why or how.

So on my synology system I don't have Send2Trash besides I don't even want to use it. So in the configuration I set "Move to trash (recycle bin) instead delete:" to false, however after a pyload restart this option goes back to True. 

And what's more annoying, if it is meant to delete, and it tries to the pyload webinterface crashes. So if I download anything as an archive - my other downloads finish but I have no access to the webinterface until I restart pyload.

title: FastCGI

milestone.title: 0.6.x
milestone.description: Far Future Release.

body:
Hello,

Could somebody have a look on FastCGI?
If it is started the following error appears and no port is opened:
ValueError: signal only works in main thread

Also tried the last fix but this fix just closes the server.

Please it would be really great to use FastCGI with nginx.

title: Update Manager settings (check interval) not persistent

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
Hi,
When changing update interval to 168h for update manager plugin, it is saved but it is not persistent for next restart (using administrate-->restart pyload). It is then restored to 8h.
Note this is working for LinkdecrypterComhook plugin.

Hey Guys, 
i have pyload running in an 10.1 Jail in FreeBSD and have these Bugs/Problems found:

``` bash
13.04.2015 10:34:35 INFO      Starting builtin webserver: 0.0.0.0:8000

Is there a way to fix this cause of a dependence problem?

title: What is the correct path encoding behaviour?

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
I've just spent ages wrestling with my freenas jail installation, trying to apply a sane UTF-8 locale, and still haven't managed to get it to apply to the pyload daemon. This means that I get `UnicodeEncodeError`s with any files that contain unicode characters, thrown when pyload checks to see if the file already exists. https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/network/HTTPChunk.py#L81

I had a look through the source code and I see that on systems that have an `ANSI` encoding, the path is forced to UTF-8. What is the reasoning behind just doing this for those systems? https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/utils.py#L49

I finally had to hack that line of code to just always encode paths to UTF-8, and was wondering if there was any change to the behaviour that might make sense here. Either always encoding to UTF-8, or maybe having an option in the config that forces encoding to UTF-8?

body:
Although it does download the package, flashgot  reports an internal error.
the root of the problems appears to be in Api.py (see below patch & traceback)

``` patch
--- ./Api.py.bad        2011-12-29 14:05:43.000000000 +0200
+++ ./Api.py    2015-02-23 01:38:54.000000000 +0200
@@ -327,7 +327,7 @@

         self.core.files.addLinks(links, pid)

-        self.core.log.info(_("Added package %(name)s containing %(count)d links") % {"name": name, "count": len(links)})
+        self.core.log.info(_("Added package %(name)s containing %(count)d links") % {"name": name.decode('utf-8'), "count": len(links)})

         self.core.files.save()

```

title: tricky wait bug
body:
I traced some very strange behavior to the following oddity. All of this happens in module.plugins, so I will omit the prefix...

hoster.OneFichierCom(module).OneFichierCom(class).handle correctly identifies a wait_time and calls

internal.SimpleHoster(module).SimpleHoster(class).wait(wait_time,...) this in turn calls

internal.SimpleHoster(module)._wait(wait_time,...) this makes two sequential calls to

(1) Plugin(module).Plugin(class).setWait(wait_time,...) and
(2) Plugin(module).Plugin(class).wait()

The first call (1) actually sets the correct wait_time in the right places, but the second call (2) always resets it to 0 seconds in the current implementation... I checked a bit how the classes are designed and used (currently). 

I would recommend to change the implementation of Plugin(module).Plugin(class).wait() as follows:

``` python
    def wait(self, seconds=None, reconnect=None):
        """ Waits the time previously set or use these from arguments. See `setWait`
        """
        if seconds:
            self.setWait(seconds, reconnect)

        pyfile = self.pyfile
        self.waiting = True

        status = pyfile.status
        pyfile.setStatus("waiting")

        self.logDebug("WAITUNTIL: %f"    % pyfile.waitUntil,
                      "RECONNECT: %s"    % self.wantReconnect)

        # rest as before
```

The major point is what the original comment already states: this method does not change the wait time, but does the actual waiting. Conversely Plugin.setWait(...) only changes the time, but doesn't do the waiting itself.

Updated in accordance with Robbi's comment.

title: filesystem encoding and filecontent encoding mixup
body:
My environment:

> sys.getdefaultencoding()
> 'ascii'
> sys.getfilesystemencoding()
> 'UTF-8'

I traced some crashes to the following problem:
The way fs_encoding/fs_decoding is set up in module.utils it is meant to handle the filesystem encoding, i.e., how filepaths are encoded. Since my filesystem encoding is utf8 no work is required there and both functions are set to lambda x:x. 

However in module.plugins.Plugin.py (line 524) fs_encoding is falsely used to encode the content of a file.

> f.write(fs_encode(res)) 

But encoding the res string (assuming the http header asked for the response to be decoded, decode=True) is really needed, because the default filecontent encoding is ascii. So not encoding it leads to a UnicodeEncodeError.

Long story short, it should be something like

> if decode: res=res.encode('utf8')
> f.write(res)

title: save_path omits forward slash on linux-like system
body:
I traced some unexpected behaviour to the following: 

In your module.utils.save_path() method the forward slash making up the path structure is dropped, i.e., 

> module.utils.save_path('/vol1/test/lala')
> 'vol1testlala'

Of course this will be irrelevant for Windows backslash-based filesystems, but for linux-like systems this is a killer making files end up on the wrong places...

title: Inconsistent Download Location with FlexGet

milestone.title: 0.6.x
milestone.description: Far Future Release.

body:
Given [this config.yml](http://pastebin.com/3Af4kQZr), pyLoad will alternately download files to their specified folders (for example: X:\Intended\Folder) or to a number of different folders in pyLoads default download folder (for example D:\default pyload download folder\Package Name, or D:\default pyload download folder\XIntendedFolder). When the package is inspected in pyLoad's webui, it shows the correct folder, and if the packages is restarted, it will download to the correct folder.
The occurrence of this issue is unpredictable: the same config.yml run back to back several times results in different outcomes.

Unfortunately neither FlexGet's trace log nor pyLoad's debug logs indicate the or any related problem, but as pyLoad does record the intended download folder correctly it would seem that the error is in pyLoad.

Semantically the folder location seems correct, as far as FlexGet goes. A number of variations have been tried, including forward slashing the path, without avail.

The most curious part of the entire problem is its intermittent nature: sometimes the download folder is correct, sometimes it is not. Sometimes, correct and incorrect folders appear in packages added in the same task, and even in the same package. Any of the three download locations defined in the config.yml, linked to above, may produce the error.

pyLoad 0.49

title: InitHomeDir.py - wrong delimiter causes trouble

milestone.title: pyLoad Next
milestone.description:
Future Release.

- All plugins updated
- Critical bugs fixup
- New UpdateManager
- New config module
- New git structure
- No setup
- Fix SSL support
- Full code refactoring
- PyPI support
- Update built-in Python 2.x to latest
- Update built-in lib to latest
- Update built-in unrar to latest

body:
I don't know much Python. As far as I understand the code in InitHomeDir.py, all passed parameters will be joined via

```
args = " ".join(argv[1:])
```

to be later split up again. And that's where the issue appears:

```
pos = args.find("--configdir=")
end = args.find("-", pos + 12)
```

I guess the reason to search for the next "-" is to look for the next parameter, but variable end will not contain the beginning position of the next parameter (and therefore the end of the passed directory for parameter -configdir=), if there is a "-" inside the given path.

The issue came to my attention, when I tried to pass a path via --configdir= and pyload used a different, yet not completely different path. Everything was right until the appearance of the first "-" in a folder.

As I already said, I don't know much Python, but why would you even join all parameters?

I did a small bugfix, which works fine for me. Replace

```
pos = args.find("--configdir=")
end = args.find("-", pos + 12)

if end == -1:
    configdir = args[pos + 12:].strip()
else:
    configdir = args[pos + 12:end].strip()
```

With

```
for aa in argv:
    if aa[0:12] == "--configdir=":
        configdir = aa[12:].strip()
```

That's it.

EDIT: Gained a little bit of knowledge on GitHub and how this all works. Submitted a pull request.

body: There are sites that don't function with FlashGot and its ability to send links to pyLoad. I build and example for you to show. ``` html Awellknownsite : Downloads & Streams » A Theory of something that happened a long time ago – Season 6 Example Link ``` Trying to add a Link via FlashGot results in the following message from FlashGot > An internal error occurred during adding the package to pyLoad. Check the pyLoad logfile for further information! The FlashGot log has the following entry: > 2014-02-16T18:10:55.566Z Preprocessing done in ms5 > 2014-02-16T18:10:55.567Z Starting dispatch > 2014-02-16T18:10:55.686Z pyLoad response status: > 500 > Internal Server Error > 2014-02-16T18:10:56.657Z Dispatch done in ms1090 > Total processing time: ms1096 At this point I'd like to mention that the logfile isn't recording that event. However pyLoadCore is printing the exception when its running in the console. And that's what it says: > Traceback (most recent call last): > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/lib/bottle.py", line 733, in _handle > return route.call(*_args) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/lib/bottle.py", line 1448, in wrapper > rv = callback(_a, *_ka) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/web/cnl_app.py", line 22, in _view > return function(_args, *_kwargs) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/web/cnl_app.py", line 134, in flashgot > PYLOAD.addPackage(package, urls, autostart) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/Api.py", line 326, in addPackage > pid = self.core.files.addPackage(name, folder, dest) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/utils.py", line 165, in new > return func(_args) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/database/FileDatabase.py", line 68, in new > return func(*args) > File "/usr/share/pyload/module/database/FileDatabase.py", line 141, in addPackage > e = InsertEvent("pack", lastID, p.order, "collector" if not queue else "queue") > AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'order' I found that somehow it had to do with the characters `»` and `–` (thats not a hyphen but some sort of dash). My conclusion is, that there are some problems with differently encoded strings. Maybe in the db. Therefor the following added to line 127 in [module/web/cnl_app.py](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/blob/stable/module/web/cnl_app.py), in flashgot() helped to make it work again: ``` python package = package.decode('utf-8', 'replace') ``` It replaces non utf-8 chars, so that pyLoad can handle the string now. In [Issue #59](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/issues/59) the [method](https://github.com/pyload/pyload/issues/59#issuecomment-16132514) I used here is mentioned. Also mentioned is that @RaNaN will change how encoding is handled in the next release, so this should only be a temporary work-around and it will be obsolete by the time a new stable version is released. I still decided to open an Issue as there might be other people experiencing this problem until then.

title: Cannot use API with default urllib

milestone.description: Old **milestone 0.5.0** *(branch master)* with new webui and core features.

body:
```
>>> from urllib import urlencode; from urllib2 import urlopen; urlopen('http://localhost:8000/api/login', urlencode({'a': 1}))
urllib2.HTTPError: HTTP Error 500: Internal Server Error
```

Strangly, it works using requests:

```
>>> import requests; requests.post('http://dollhouse:8000/api/login')
<Response [200]>
```

It turns out that this is because urllib2 only sets this Accpet-Encoding header:

```
Accept-Encoding: identity
```

Things look better when I add gzip manually:

```
>>> import urllib2; headers = { 'Accept' : '*/*', 'Accept-Encoding': 'identity, gzip'}; re = urllib2.Request('http://localhost:8000/api/login', "", headers); urllib2.urlopen(re)
<addinfourl at 41238752 whose fp = <socket._fileobject object at 0x27466d0>>
```

I should say that I am using pyload as packaged by http://spk.unzureichende.info/ for Synology, using 0.4.9-4.
